‎05-12-2010 03:21 AM

thomas508 (5/11/2010)
I was only diagnosed last week and have been on the Metformin and watching what I eat for 5 days now. My numbers have been slowly going down but this morning after fasting all night it was 9 points higher than last night before bed, is this a normal thing? I have had lower numbers each morning so far. I realize that I am new and after only 5 days I will probably have ups and downs but that was my one consistent so far, that I would have my lowest reading each morning.
G'day Thomas

This may help you understand what is happening overnight (click on the coloured text): I Ate Nothing! Why Are My BGs high?
Cheers, Alan, Type 2, d&e metformin 2000mg, Australia.
Everything in Moderation - Except Laughter.
There is nothing I could eat I like more than my eyes.
Type 2 Diabetes - A Personal Journey(latest: Fat: The New Health Paradigm)
Born Under a Wandering Star (Latest: Ella to Kandy, Sri Lanka)

‎05-12-2010 07:00 PM

Thomas508 (5/11/2010)
Ok, here�s another. What is the best way to log & track your numbers? I started writing it down on paper then I made an Excel spreadsheet for it but I�m not sure I like that either. My meter is the OneTouch Ultra 2 and they have software with a USB cord so you can plug it in your pc and upload it into their software. I think I may buy that but I�m not sure I want to spend the money when I don�t know for sure how well the software is or what all it does.

Billy


I'm not sure if LifeScan has fixed the problem or not, but if you have a 64 bit computer, the cable is not compatible. If you have an older, 32 bit, it works fine. Fortunately for me, I had an older desktop to plug the cable into, but it wouldn't work with my newer laptop. Funny thing is, the software itself works great on either system, it was just the cable that didn't work for me.
Talvie


"Life shrinks or expands in proportion to one's courage." Anais Nin
Type 2 Diabetes diagnosed December 13, 2000 w/A1c of 7.6. June 2014 A1c 5.6 Controlling with diet and exercise, and 500mg daily of metformin.

‎05-12-2010 11:21 PM

It wasn't the version of Windows that was the problem, as I had Vista on the new computer and Windows XP on the older computer. (I've since updated the laptop to Windows 7). It had more to do with the computer itself. You might want to check out your "System Properties" for how many bits your operating system has. I called Life Scan to find out if they had a cable that was compatible with my 64 bit operating system and I was told that they didn't have one, but that was about six months ago.
Talvie


"Life shrinks or expands in proportion to one's courage." Anais Nin

‎05-12-2010 11:44 PM

Thomas,

To get around having the newer 64 and not older 32 bit cpu. Windows 7 vice all the rest prior.

I downloaded some free did I say FREE pages from a website, up front I don't work for them nor endorse them by letting you have the HTTP: but they have Blood Pressure- Insulin Injection Log - Blood Sugar Log + others. Download each page you wish to use to WORD and then you just need to type in on date and when (lunch before and after BG numbers) as your meter indicates. You can then resize each page before printing and print 'em. I take each three months with me to PCP at A1c and blood panel time. She keeps those in my PCP office record and we discuss what's printed ( my PCP does discuss T2 and treatments with me, some here will tell you their PCP don't even when handed the print-outs).

http://www.americanmedical-id.com/about_us/med_form_intro.php

This is a safe site to download from! You may store sheets on cpu or print to anysize and sore elsewhere.

And welcome to boards!

Promise me you'll always remember:
"You're Braver than you believe, Stronger that you seem, and Smarter than you think !"

Christopher Robin to Pooh Bear

Lee, T2 since 07/1988
Live long and prosper.

"Don't waste any tomorrows because of what you didn't do yesterday !"

‎05-12-2010 11:56 PM

thomas508 (5/12/2010)
Both are 32 bit systems, thanks. The only thing I read was that it wouldn't run on Windows 7, they may have just had a 64 bit system and that was the problem. I can't remember where I read it now. So you like the software?

Billy


I do like it. It produces some really neat reports that you can take with you to the doctor's office. Graphs, too, if you want them. It gives you a place to put notes and that's helpful if something unusual was going on at the time you tested. It highlights high numbers and low numbers -- you set your ranges, so it's not arbitrary -- and if you have a color printer available, it'll print out color coded reports. It's well worth the money, in my opinion.
Talvie


"Life shrinks or expands in proportion to one's courage." Anais Nin
Type 2 Diabetes diagnosed December 13, 2000 w/A1c of 7.6. June 2014 A1c 5.6 Controlling with diet and exercise, and 500mg daily of metformin.

‎05-12-2010 11:56 PM

I did like the software but had to replace my cpu and all that was operating system was new window 7, 64 bit!!

They promise to get a 64 bit out soon cause more 64bits are being used now in homes. Until then I use the site I gave you prior and just saved sheets to WORD and type in BG data. The entry doesn't take log from meter to sheets. I call up input numbers on meter and type that where it belongs on sheets. Better than making self done spreadsheets and time spent doing such.
